answers.author: Municipal Meerkat
answers.text:
This is a very difficult question to answer due to the extremely large variation in municipality populations. My borrow is little more than my extended family. While San Antonio, the largest professionally managed city in the US, has a population of well over 1 million people. 
As of July 1, 2008 the Census Bureau estimated that there were 304,059,000 individuals residing within the US. Also, according to the National League of Cities there are approximately 19,429 independent municipal governments throughout the United States. From a purely mathematical standpoint, the average population of a US city would be 15,649 residents (304mill / 19,429). However, this number is an average and may be positively skewed due to the relatively few cities with very large populations, i.e. San Antonio. 
If you were to look at a population distribution of US cities, you would find that a very large number of cities would fall below this 15,000 resident threshold. A median population of US cities would be a much better indicator of the “average” size of US cities.  The median population for US cities would probably be around 6,000 residents.

answers.author: Larry Paine
answers.text:
One of the articles posted to the board (Tool Box) suggests that a small city is 25,000 or less and with 100 or fewer employees.  I have a problem with that for a very long time.  Even a population of 10,000 might be stretching it.
An old phrase I learned plays into the defination "where you stand determines what you see."  I suppose if you worked in San Antonio 25,000 would be small.  Here in Kansas, we have 627 cities, 591 are smaller than 10,000. That 591 has 25% of the state's population.

answers.author: Pamela Caskie
answers.text:
I would like to suggest that the answer doesn't necessarily lie in population, budgets, or number of employees but instead staffing.  My thinking is that a small community does not have professionally trained staff in all department head positions, the city manager usually has to pick up one or two functional responsibilities -- such as personnel, finance, risk management on their own, and there is not many staff (as opposed to line) employees around to do the extra tasks -- grant applications, analysis, research, or facilitation of meetings and trainings.    
It is my contention that small cities without these capacities are at a disadvantage when it comes to the implementation of many of the "new" ideas that are out there.  Performance measurement is great but what small city has the staff time to truly document the activities for measurement the way they should be.  And that is just one of many examples of not having a full complement of staff impacts small communities.
It would be my hope that among other things, this ICMA group could be a forum for discussing how to bring "best practices" to our small cities within the resources that we all have available.

answers.author: Scot Simpson
answers.text:
How about "banding" communities in ICMA rather than use "small" or "large"    This could be done according to where the membership falls.  If 30% of communities served by ICMA members are 5,000 or less then that could be a band. This may make programs, workshops, websites, KN, etc. more beneficial if they indicated what band they would be targeting. 
You can always choose to ignore the audience targets. Just because my community is only 15,000 doesn't mean I can't learn from a program for 5,000 and under or 50,000 and over. However, how San Jose reorganized its 50-person economic development agency may not be that relevant(right now).
